titlestmt.sponsor: This collection-level EAD record is a product of the Philadelphia Area Consortium of Special Collections Libraries (PACSCL) Consortial Survey Initiative, which was funded by the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation.

profiledesc.creation: Machine-readable finding aid generated in EAD from data in the PACSCL Consortial Survey Database on 12/21/2012. Modified by Dot Porter in 2017.

bioghist.p: Fiske Kimball (1888-1955) was a distinguished architectural historian and director of the Philadelphia Museum of Art. From his appointment in 1925 until his retirement in 1955, he steered the institution, transforming it from what he described as "a minor provincial position to become one of the leading museums of America." Before coming to the Museum, Kimball was professor of architecture and fine arts at the University of Michigan (1912-1919), professor of art and architecture at the University of Virginia (1919-1923), and was in charge of the fine arts department at New York University (1923-1925). He was the author of Domestic Architecture of the American Colonies (1922), American Architecture (1928), and The Creation of the Rococo (1943).

scopecontent.p: This collection is an accrual to the Fiske Kimball papers. It consists of glass negatives and lantern slides depicting American and European painting, sculpture, architecture, and furniture from the Renaissance to the modern period. The collection also includes film negatives. Kimball used these images in lectures on architecture and fine arts.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

relatedmaterial.p: Related material may be found in the following collections: Philadelphia Museum of Art: Fiske Kimball Papers, 1874-1957 (Series IV, Teaching positions, includes slide lists for lectures)
